topics.title: What is Brolli?
topics.answer:
Brolli is a 1-year renewable patent license delivered as a soulbound NFT.

It's meant to be a simple, checkable proof that a specific wallet address holds the license.

Constraints:
- One per wallet
- Team purchases require one wallet per seat
- Total supply capped at 50
- Price is $99 during the promotion

topics.title: What do I actually get when I buy?
topics.answer: A soulbound license NFT minted to your wallet, plus a provenance reference (IPFS) that points to the patent + terms bundle, and an on-chain expiry timestamp.

topics.title: Can my team buy multiple licenses?
topics.answer: Yes—one per wallet. Practical workflow: collect wallet addresses and buy one license per address.

topics.title: Is it transferable?
topics.answer: No. It's soulbound (non-transferable) by design.

topics.title: What should we show investors in diligence?
topics.answer: The wallet holding the NFT, the on-chain expiry timestamp, and the provenance reference in the NFT metadata. It's designed to be quick to verify.

topics.title: What is a BUIDLer?
topics.answer:
A BUIDLer is someone who actively builds real products and infrastructure in the blockchain ecosystem (not just speculation).

It's a play on the HODL meme: "BUIDL" means build. In practice: devs, founders, and engineers who ship code, deploy protocols, and solve real-world problems—often in fintech, DeFi, RWA, and infrastructure.

BUIDLers care about functionality, compliance, scalability, and long-term utility.

topics.title: Who should buy it (company vs founders vs product wallet)?
topics.answer:
Buy for the wallet identity you want covered as proof (usually the company’s operational wallet).

If multiple people/agents need coverage, issue one per wallet.

topics.title: How long does Brolli last?
topics.answer:
The license is time-limited and renewable.

On-chain it's represented as an expiry timestamp for the covered wallet. Renewals extend from the later of "now" or "current expiry."

topics.title: What included?
topics.answer:
Included: the specific license grant described in the provenance/terms.

Not included: specific IP protection, litigation outcomes, or guarantees you won’t be sued.

topics.title: How does Brolli reduce agentic commerce risk?
topics.answer:
Agents can scale behavior fast; they also scale exposure fast.

Brolli is positioned as a simple risk-reduction move for a specific category of IP tail risk while you iterate in regulated markets.

topics.title: Does Brolli take care of my KYC/AML/sanctions compliance?
topics.answer:
No.

This product is an IP license. You still need your own compliance program and controls for your regulated activity.

topics.title: What do you mean by Dirty IP risk?
topics.answer:
"Dirty IP" is the practical risk that broad patent claims and asymmetric enforcement can create for startups.

The existential problem usually isn't whether you're morally right; it's that litigation cost, uncertainty, and timing can cripple a young company right when it has traction.

Brolli is positioned as umbrella protection while you build: reduce a category of tail risk cheaply so you can focus on shipping and distribution.

topics.title: How does Brolli affect my IP strategy?
topics.answer:
It gives you time to decide without spending a fortune on legal fees.

For most early-stage teams, filing early often competes with runway and velocity. A patent is a strategy (and sometimes an enforcement tool), not a default badge.

A practical approach is:
- Keep shipping and learning what’s truly worth protecting
- Reduce catastrophic tail risk cheaply (umbrella coverage)
- Revisit a deeper IP strategy once you have traction, budget, and a clear reason to enforce

topics.title: Can you patent a business process?
topics.answer:
Sometimes, but it’s often a distraction for early-stage teams.

Business process patents can be expensive, slow, and hard to enforce. Many startups end up spending time and money on IP work before they’ve proven distribution or product-market fit.

If you’re early-stage, optimize for shipping and derisking. Decide on a deeper IP strategy later when the business can support it.

topics.title: Real-world example of IP enforcement being crippling
topics.answer:
One real-world example people cite is Thomson Reuters v. Ross Intelligence. Without taking a position on who was "right," it illustrates a founder reality: IP disputes with giants will put you out of business.

That's the point of planning for tail risk early: you don't want a legal fight to become the thing that decides whether your product survives.

topics.title: What data do you collect?
topics.answer:
Wallet address and public on-chain activity.

Avoid sharing sensitive information in chat.

topics.title: What if we rotate wallets or lose keys?
topics.answer:
Because the NFT is soulbound, wallet rotation is non-trivial.

Treat the covered wallet as critical infrastructure and plan custody and key management accordingly.
